articles.headline: Wrenching Choice in South Sudan: Starve or Risk Rape
articles.snippet: Clashes between the country’s rival factions halted food distribution for tens of thousands of people in United Nations camps, and sexual violence has risen.
articles.abstract: Clashes between the country’s rival factions halted food distribution for tens of thousands of people in United Nations camps, and sexual violence has risen.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUBA, South Sudan — At a sprawling displacement camp on the outskirts of the capital, women have faced a wrenching choice: risk starvation or sexual assault.

articles.headline: Shocker! Facebook Changes Its Algorithm to Avoid ‘Clickbait’
articles.snippet: A change in the social network’s algorithm is meant to identify misleading headlines on news stories and rank them lower, to keep users coming back.
articles.abstract: A change in the social network’s algorithm is meant to identify misleading headlines on news stories and rank them lower, to keep users coming back.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook says it plans to marginalize what it considers to be “clickbait” news stories from publishers in its news feed, in another step to keep its 1.71 billion members regularly coming back to its social network.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Everyone Despises SolarCity Deal, Except Tesla Shareholders
articles.snippet: Focusing on the conflicts of interest in Tesla Motors’ proposed takeover of SolarCity misses the bigger picture, some investors say.
articles.abstract: Focusing on the conflicts of interest in Tesla Motors’ proposed takeover of SolarCity misses the bigger picture, some investors say.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s an understatement to say Tesla Motors’ proposed $2.6 billion takeover of SolarCity has been the most reviled deal of the year.

articles.headline: Colombia’s New, Legal Drug Barons Focus on Medical Marijuana
articles.snippet: Colombia revised a 30-year-old drug law and embraced medical marijuana; now private companies are betting that cannabis could be a market leader.
articles.abstract: Colombia revised a 30-year-old drug law and embraced medical marijuana; now private companies are betting that cannabis could be a market leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIONEGRO, Colombia — Like many drug barons in Colombia, Federico Cock-Correa wants to sell his product globally. Just 15 miles outside Medellín, Mr. Cock-Correa is looking to replace vast acres of flowers with marijuana plants, with plans to export the harvest.

articles.headline: Bar Association Considers Striking ‘Honeys’ From the Courtroom
articles.snippet: An effort to bar sexist or discriminatory comments by lawyers addressing each other has been criticized for inhibiting the ability to speak freely.
articles.abstract: An effort to bar sexist or discriminatory comments by lawyers addressing each other has been criticized for inhibiting the ability to speak freely.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Lori Rifkin asked the opposing lawyer to stop interrupting her while she questioned a potential witness, he replied: “Don’t raise your voice at me. It’s not becoming of a woman.”

articles.headline: They Want Trump to Make the G.O.P. a Workers’ Party
articles.snippet: Conservative thinkers have felt emboldened to press their party to reshape its canon to more directly benefit the workers it has often taken for granted.
articles.abstract: Conservative thinkers have felt emboldened to press their party to reshape its canon to more directly benefit the workers it has often taken for granted.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By riding his appeal among working-class whites to the top of the Republican Party, Donald J. Trump has emboldened conservative thinkers to press their party of business and the privileged to reshape its economic canon to more directly benefit poorer workers it has often taken for granted.

articles.headline: Strong Job Gains, for Second Month, Reframe Economic Outlook
articles.snippet: The new data undercuts Republican arguments that the recovery is faltering and suggests that workers are seeing benefits from the drop in unemployment.
articles.abstract: The new data undercuts Republican arguments that the recovery is faltering and suggests that workers are seeing benefits from the drop in unemployment.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American jobs machine has moved back into high gear.

articles.headline: Afghanistan Is in Chaos. Is That What Hamid Karzai Wants?
articles.snippet: Critics say the former president is working from the wings to destabilize his successor’s government. He says he has no interest in returning to power.
articles.abstract: Critics say the former president is working from the wings to destabilize his successor’s government. He says he has no interest in returning to power.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Hamid Karzai, the former Afghan president and current antagonist to his successor’s government, likes to describe Afghan politics as a marathon.

articles.headline: This Is a Jobs Report That Democrats Can Boast About
articles.snippet: Political science research points to changes in income as being predictors of how people vote, and things were looking up in the July numbers.
articles.abstract: Political science research points to changes in income as being predictors of how people vote, and things were looking up in the July numbers.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s not much to say about the July jobs numbers beyond this: They’re good news across the board.

articles.headline: Zen and the Art of 401(k) Maintenance
articles.snippet: How often should you check the performance of your investments? As seldom as possible — especially when markets are falling.
articles.abstract: How often should you check the performance of your investments? As seldom as possible — especially when markets are falling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s how to get better returns in your retirement account: Pay as little attention to it as possible.

articles.headline: Immunotherapy Drug Opdivo Fails Clinical Trial to Expand Use
articles.snippet: Bristol-Myers Squibb said the drug had not slowed the progression of advanced lung cancer in a test seeking approval to use it as an initial treatment.
articles.abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb said the drug had not slowed the progression of advanced lung cancer in a test seeking approval to use it as an initial treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hot new field of immunotherapy got a shock on Friday when a best-selling new drug failed as an initial treatment for lung cancer in a clinical trial.
